title: Protect Those Paws from Ice and Salt
description: Winter streets are often treated with salt and de-icers that can irritate and damage your pet's paws. Always wipe their paws after walks to remove any chemicals.
detailedTips: Use pet-safe ice melts around your home
Consider waterproof booties for extreme conditions
Apply paw balm before walks to create a protective barrier
Check for ice balls between toes after walks

title: Watch for Hypothermia Signs
description: Pets can get hypothermia just like humans. Know the signs and act quickly if you notice shivering, weakness, or shallow breathing.
detailedTips: Limit outdoor time in extreme cold (below 20¬∞F)
Use sweaters or coats for short-haired breeds
Watch for pale or blue gums - a sign of circulation issues
Dry your pet thoroughly after being in snow or rain

title: Adjust Feeding for Winter Activity Levels
description: Indoor pets may need fewer calories in winter, while active outdoor pets might need more. Monitor weight and adjust food accordingly.
detailedTips: Reduce portions for less active indoor pets by 10-15%
Increase high-quality protein for outdoor working dogs
Provide warm meals to help maintain body temperature
Consult your vet for breed-specific dietary adjustments

title: Create Cozy Indoor Spaces
description: Ensure your pet has warm, draft-free sleeping areas away from cold floors and windows during winter months.
detailedTips: Elevate beds off cold floors
Use thermal or self-warming pet beds
Place beds away from drafts and exterior doors
Add extra blankets for nesting

title: Never Leave Pets in Cold Cars
description: Cars act like refrigerators in winter, holding in the cold. Never leave your pet unattended in a vehicle during cold weather.
detailedTips: Cars can reach freezing temperatures quickly
Pets left in cars risk hypothermia
Run all errands before taking pets home
If you must travel with pets, never leave them alone

title: Grooming Adjustments for Winter
description: Proper winter grooming helps maintain insulation. Avoid shaving down to the skin and consider longer coats for protection.
detailedTips: Don't shave double-coated breeds in winter
Regular brushing helps maintain insulating undercoat
Trim hair between toes to prevent ice buildup
Bathe less frequently to preserve natural oils

title: Check Under Car Hoods
description: Outdoor cats and small animals often seek warmth in car engines. Always check and tap your hood before starting the car in winter.
detailedTips: Knock on hood or honk horn before starting engine
Check wheel wells and undercarriage
Keep outdoor cats indoors during extreme cold
Provide outdoor shelter alternatives

title: Provide Fresh, Unfrozen Water
description: Pets can become dehydrated in winter too. Ensure they always have access to fresh, unfrozen water both indoors and outdoors.
detailedTips: Use heated water bowls for outdoor pets
Check water frequently for freezing
Add warm water to meals for extra hydration
Monitor water intake - pets drink less in cold

title: Winter Exercise Alternatives
description: When it's too cold for outdoor activities, provide indoor exercise and mental stimulation to keep your pet healthy and happy.
detailedTips: Create indoor obstacle courses
Use puzzle toys and treat dispensers
Practice obedience training indoors
Schedule playdates in indoor facilities

title: Recognize Frostbite in Pets
description: Frostbite most commonly affects ears, tails, and paws. Know the signs: pale, gray, or blue skin that's cold and hard to the touch.
detailedTips: Check extremities after cold exposure
Seek immediate vet care for suspected frostbite
Warm affected areas gradually with warm towels
Never rub frostbitten areas - it causes more damage

title: Senior Pet Winter Care
description: Older pets need extra attention in cold weather. Arthritis can worsen, and they're more susceptible to temperature changes.
detailedTips: Provide orthopedic beds with extra padding
Use pet-safe heating pads
Shorter, more frequent potty breaks
Consider joint supplements (consult your vet)

title: Holiday Safety Precautions
description: Winter holidays bring unique hazards. Keep pets safe from decorations, toxic plants, and holiday foods.
detailedTips: Secure Christmas trees to prevent tipping
Avoid tinsel and small ornaments
Keep pets away from poinsettias and lilies
No sharing holiday sweets or fatty foods
